results.title: The Initial interview
results.brief_description: A marriage counselling session is presented, showing the initial interview. Afterwards a class of marriage counsellors are taught by flashbacks highlighting important moments of the interview. Role playing is introduced to mitigate the problems and fears of counsellors; interaction promotes emotional involvement of student counsellors.

results.title: The Trombone
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”
Alfred Flaszynski describes the history of the trombone, its development and the technique of playing, illustrated by excerpts from Ravel’s Bolero and George Lohmann’s Posaune Teufel. The problems of selecting each note by the correct use of the slide and the appropriate harmonic series are dealt with in detail.

results.title: Nightshade for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve, manual and epilepsy warning sheet in cardboard box
results.brief_description: After Metro City’s local superhero Vortex is killed, the power vacuum leads to a villain named Sutekh taking control of the city’s gangs and enveloping the city in crime. Only one person can stop them: A vigilante named Nightshade. The game is a point-and-click adventure, meaning the player can examine and interact with the environment, talk to the citizens of Metro City and fight Sutekh’s minions. The game boasts a ‘Personality Gauge’ which changes based on the player’s actions. Increased popularity has gameplay implications such as additional information from grateful citizens. Despite the dark setting, the game itself is light in tone and is filled with jokes and pop culture references.

results.title: Collected stories of the XPT
results.creator_credit: Cathy Beitz, Kath McIntryre and Banksia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
On the Express Passenger Train, experience the fastest form of land transport between Australia’s two major capital cities, Melbourne and Sydney. Reaching speeds up to 70 miles per hour, the XPT travels across rolling plains and through the country’s Great Dividing Range. See rural areas rich with the history of early settlers who continued the struggles they imported from England and Ireland, including the outlaw, Ned Kelly. Visit the border town of Albury and find out about Australia’s unique railroad history. The town of Goulburn, home to the largest jail in the Southern Hemisphere, offers an insight into modern Aboriginal history. The view out the window of this train reveals a hundred fascinating observations about Australia and it’s people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cathy Beitz, Kath McIntryre and Banksia Productions

results.title: [The Fridge]
results.brief_description: An ant attempts to climb to the top of the family fridge. As he scales towards the summit - dressed in his mountain climbing gear - an accident prevents him from achieving his goal. His tragic downfall is captured by photographers.

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Paul Tortelier, the French cellist and composer, conducts a master-class of four members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain and instructs them in some of the finer points in the Dvorak Cell Concerto. Tortelier gives a history of cello playing and the film ends with an excerpt from the great Cello Concerto by Lalo.

results.title: The Ghan: a spiritual connection
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
The legendary Ghan was named after the Afghans who with their camels opened the supply line through Australia’s interior. On this rich and fascinating journey from Adelaide to the Red Centre of Australia, traverse some of the world’s most ancient and inhospitable terrain, exploring the history of this great train line. At the remote town of Pimba, attend a rock concert in the middle of the Australian desert, arranged by the world music organisation WOMAD. Later, when the Ghan pulls into Alice Springs, visit Uluru, the largest free standing rock in the world. Uluru is a sacred aboriginal dreaming site that was returned to it’s original owners in 1985 and is now one of Australia’s most celebrated tourist attractions.
